title: Generosity & Giving
description: Explore how you think about giving—to each other, to others, and what generosity means to you.

questions.text: When it comes to giving gifts, I tend to...
choices: Put a lot of thought into finding the perfect thing
Keep it simple and practical
Prefer experiences over physical gifts
Give spontaneously when something feels right

therapeutic.rationale: Gift-giving styles often reflect love languages and values. Thoughtful givers show love through effort; practical givers show love through usefulness; experience-givers prioritize memories; spontaneous givers follow intuition. Mismatched expectations can lead to disappointment on both sides.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The thoughtful giver may feel the practical giver doesn't care; the practical giver may feel pressured by elaborate expectations. Share what gifts mean to you—it's about the meaning, not the price tag.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched gift styles make celebrations easier. You'll naturally give in ways that land well.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's the best gift you've ever received? What made it special—the item or the meaning behind it?

questions.text: When one of us wants to spend money on the other, I believe...
choices: It should feel balanced over time
Whoever has more should give more freely
We shouldn't keep score
It depends on what we're each comfortable with

therapeutic.rationale: Beliefs about reciprocity in giving reveal deeper values about fairness, generosity, and partnership. Some need balance to feel equal; others give freely without tracking. Unspoken expectations create resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The balance-seeker may feel taken advantage of; the no-score-keeper may feel the relationship is being transactionalized. Name your belief and understand your partner's.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared beliefs make giving feel natural. But check in—circumstances change, and so might feelings about balance.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you keep track of who's given more? How does imbalance (real or perceived) make you feel?

questions.text: When it comes to giving to family or friends, I feel...
choices: We should be generous when we can
We need to take care of ourselves first
It depends on the situation and who's asking
We should discuss it together before committing

therapeutic.rationale: Generosity to others outside the relationship can create tension—especially when one partner feels the other is overgiving or withholding. Values about family obligation, friendship, and boundaries all play in.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The generous giver may feel the cautious partner is selfish; the cautious partner may feel the giver doesn't prioritize them. Both are usually trying to protect something important.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared giving values prevent a common conflict. You'll naturally agree on when to help and when to hold back.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Has giving to others ever caused tension in a relationship? What was really at stake?

questions.text: The most meaningful way to be generous with my partner is...
choices: Giving my time and attention
Surprising them with thoughtful gestures
Supporting their goals and dreams
Being there when things are hard

therapeutic.rationale: Generosity isn't just about money—it's about what you give of yourself. Knowing how your partner experiences generosity helps you give in ways that actually land.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: You may be generous in ways your partner doesn't fully register. The time-giver may not realize their partner needs more surprise gestures. Ask: 'How do you most feel my generosity?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched generosity values mean you'll naturally give what each other treasures. Lean into it.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When has your partner been generous with you in a way that really touched you? Did you tell them?

questions.text: When we disagree about whether to spend on something, I'd want us to...
choices: Talk it through until we're both comfortable
Defer to whoever feels more strongly
Find a compromise that works for both
Take time to think before deciding together

therapeutic.rationale: How you navigate spending disagreements predicts how you'll handle financial conflict generally. This is less about the money and more about how you make decisions together when you don't agree.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conflict styles need bridging. The talk-it-through person may feel the defer-to-one approach avoids real conversation; the compromise-seeker may get frustrated by endless discussion. Name your style.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched decision styles make disagreements smoother—though any style has pitfalls. Know your shared tendency's blind spots.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Think of a recent disagreement about spending. How did you resolve it? What would you do differently?
